Paragraph (5) is amended to read as follows:
Class 4 Property shall be comprised of all improved real property that appears as blighted vacant on the list compiled under ยง 42-3131.16(a)(2).

The Office of Tax and Revenue may request the Mayor to inspect improved real property to determine whether the property is correctly designated as blighted vacant on the list compiled under ยง 42-3131.16(a)(2).
Subsection (d-1) is amended as follows:
Paragraph (4A) is amended by striking the phrase "under ยง 42-3131.16 or ยง 42-3131.17" and inserting the phrase "under ยง 42-3131.16" in its place.
Paragraph (5)(A-i), (B), and (C) are amended to read follows:
Whenever the classification of improved real property that appears on a list compiled under ยง 42-3131.16 shall change to Class 3 or Class 4 Property:

The owner shall notify the Department of Buildings within 30 days of the change by making application to register the property as vacant under ยง 42-3131.06, and the change in classification of the real property to Class 3 or 4 Property shall be retroactive to the half tax year during which one of the following first occurred:
The owner of the real property registered the real property as vacant under ยง 42-3131.06; or
The owner of real property received a notice of final determination under ยง 42-3131.15, or the time period to issue a notice of final determination under that section has expired;
The Office of Tax and Revenue shall re-classify the real property without limitation for each tax year or half tax year after receipt of the list under ยง 42-3131.16; and

Penalty and interest as prescribed under ยง 47-811(c) shall be assessed beginning 30 days after the date of the real property tax bill that issues after any administrative appeals have been exhausted.

Whenever improved real property that appears on a list compiled under ยง 42-3131.16 shall cease to be Class 3 or Class 4 Property, the owner shall notify the Department of Buildings within 30 days after the change in the manner as may be prescribed by the Mayor. If the request for a change in classification is approved, the change in classification of the real property from Class 3 or Class 4 Property shall be retroactive to the half tax year when the Department of Buildings was so notified. If the request is denied, the owner shall have a right to administrative review of the determination as provided under ยง 42-3131.15.

Notwithstanding subparagraph (A-i) of this paragraph, if the real property is transferred and continued to qualify for the classification 30 days or less before the date of execution of the deed of transfer, the grantor shall not be required to notify the applicable agency of the change in classification.
If the tax is paid within 30 days of the corresponding bill, timely notification of the change in classification shall preclude assessment of penalty and interest.

The lead-in language of subsection (d-2) is amended by striking the phrase "Class 3 Property or Class 4 Property," and inserting the phrase "Class 2 Property, Class 3 Property, or Class 4 Property," in its place.
A new subsection (d-3) is added to read as follows:
If real property changes classification to Class 1A Property as defined in subsection (c-9)(2)(A)(ii) during the period of:

October 1 through March 31 of the tax year, the newly reclassified Class 1A Property, or the portion thereof used exclusively for residential purposes if already improved or assessed under ยง 47-829, shall be taxed at the Class 1A Property tax rate for the entire tax year; or

April 1 through September 30 of the tax year, the newly reclassified Class 1A Property, or the portion thereof used exclusively for residential purposes if already improved or assessed under ยง 47-829, shall be taxed at the Class 1A Property tax rate for the second installment only.

The owner shall apply for a change of classification to Class 1A Property as defined in subsection (c-9)(2)(A)(ii) of this section and shall promptly provide complete documentation in a manner prescribed by the Chief Financial Officer to substantiate any such classification change before it shall be effective.

A change in classification to Class 1A Property as defined in subsection (c-9)(2)(A)(ii) of this section shall be effective beginning in the half tax year for which application is made under paragraph (2) of this subsection.

If change in classification to Class 1A Property as defined in subsection (c-9)(2)(A)(ii) of this section is determined to be erroneous because the real property was not put to predominantly residential use 3 years from issuance of the permit, the Chief Financial Officer shall reclassify and tax the real property without limitation for each tax year or half tax year in which the real property was improperly classified as Class 1A Property, subject only to subsection (d-1)(5)(A-i) of this section, if the property is determined to be Class 3 Property or Class 4 Property, or subsection (d-2) of this section. In the event of such reclassification, penalty and interest shall be added beginning from the day the correct amount of tax should have been due but not paid if the property had been properly classified.

Within 45 days from the date of the notice of denial of Class 1A Property reclassification under this subsection, the owner may petition for an administrative review of the rescission or denial and appeal from a final determination thereof to the same extent as if the appeal were filed under ยง 47-825.01a(d)(2).

Notwithstanding the time limitations in paragraphs (4) and (5) of this subsection, the Chief Financial Officer, in his or her discretion, may grant an extension of time to comply or waive penalty and interest assessed pursuant to paragraph (4) of this subsection to prevent an undue hardship to the owner.

The provisions of this subsection, subsection (c-9)(2)(A)(ii) of this section, and ยง 47-829 shall not supersede the requirement to timely file for mixed-use classification for the upcoming tax year pursuant to subsection (f) of this section, when the annual assessment for such upcoming tax year is made under ยง 47-824 and the certificate of occupancy (final or temporary) was issued.

container.heading: FORECLOSURE BY THE OFFICE OF THE ATTORNEY GENERAL OF VACANT AND BLIGHTED PROPERTIES.

section.text: Chapter 13A of Title 47 of the District of Columbia Official Code is amended as follows:

para.text: The table of contents is amended by adding a new subchapter designation to read as follows:

container.heading: Foreclosure by the Office of the Attorney General of Class 3 and 4 Properties.

section.heading: Eligibility to foreclose on a Class 3 or 4 Property.

para.text: Section 47-1330 is amended as follows:
New paragraphs (1A) and (1B) are added to read as follows:
"Class 3 property" shall have the same meaning as set forth in ยง 47-813(c-9)(4)(A).
"Class 4 property" shall have the same meaning as set forth in ยง 47-813(c-9)(5)(A).
Paragraph (4A) is redesignated as Paragraph (4B)
A new paragraph (4A) is added to read as follows:
"Interested party" means any person having an interest in real property:
Who last appears as owner of the property on the Office of Tax and Revenue's real property records;
Who is a mortgagee of the property or assignee of a mortgage of record;
Who is holder of a beneficial interest in a deed of trust recorded against the property; or
Whose identity and address are:
Reasonably ascertainable from land records with the Recorder of Deeds;
Revealed by a full title search going back in time at least 50 years; or

In the event a record owner is deceased and no personal representative of the deceased owner's estate has been appointed, revealed by a search in accordance with generally accepted standards of probate decisions of the Superior Court.
Section 47-1332(c) is amended to read as follows:
The Mayor shall not sell any real property if:
A forbearance authorization has been approved in writing by the Mayor for the applicable tax sale;
The owner enters into a payment plan pursuant to ยง 47-811.05 prior to the date of the tax sale;
For an improved Class 1A or 1B Property, the tax amount to be sold is less than $4,000;

The real property is a Class 1A or 1B Property that is receiving a homestead deduction, with respect to which there is an outstanding non-void certificate of sale; provided, that no real property shall be excluded from sale solely pursuant to this paragraph if the non-void certificate of sale has been outstanding for 3 years or more; or

For a Class 3 or Class 4 property registered or designated as vacant or designated as blighted vacant, the owner has been delinquent for less than one year and the right to appeal a final determination of vacancy or blight has been exhausted by the owner.
A new subchapter V is added to read as follows:

container.heading: Foreclosure by the Attorney General of Class 3 and 4 Properties.

section.heading: Eligibility to foreclose on a Class 3 or 4 Property.

para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the Office of the Attorney General ("Office") shall file a complaint with the Superior Court of the District of Columbia to foreclose the right of redemption for a Class 3 or 4 property for which there is a real property tax delinquency after:
The expiration of one year from the date of delinquency;
The right to appeal a final determination of vacancy or blight has been exhausted by the owner; and
The Mayor has provided notice pursuant to ยง 47-1391.

The Office may decline to file a complaint with Superior Court, or may dismiss a pending complaint, if the Office ascertains, through application by an interested party or pursuant to the Office's own review and investigation, that:
An interested party paid the amount set forth in the pre-complaint notice provided pursuant to ยง 47-1391;
An interested party proves that the real property identified in the pre-complaint notice provided pursuant to ยง 47-1391 meets the definition of occupied in ยง 42-3131.05(8)(A);
An interested party proves:
A failure of the Mayor to mail the notices required by ยงยง 47-1341(a) or 47-1391; or

That the mailing address of the person who last appears as the record owner of the real property on the tax roll, as properly updated by the record owner by the filing of a change of address with the Office of Tax and Revenue in accordance with ยง 42-405, was not correctly or substantively updated by the Office of Tax and Revenue notwithstanding proper filing;
The foreclosure would result in substantial personal and economic hardship;
An interested party has the intent and ability to return and occupy, rehabilitate, or sell the property within one year's time; or

Proceeding with the foreclosure would not be in the best interest of the District, including because it would delay the Office's ability to timely pursue foreclosure litigation on other nuisance properties.

After declining to file a complaint or dismissing a complaint pursuant to subsection (b) of this section, the Office shall publish notice of the action in the District of Columbia Register. The notice shall contain the name of the owner, the address of the property, and the date on which the exemption from immediate sale was approved or the date on which the pending complaint was dismissed.".

No less than 90 days prior to the filing of a complaint with the Court pursuant to ยง 47-1392, the Mayor shall send written notice to the owner or owners of record of the property at such owner's mailing address as updated in the Office of Tax and Revenue's real property records.

The notice shall inform the owner or owners of record of the property of the intent to file a complaint to foreclose the right of redemption. The notice shall also contain the amount of real property tax due as of the day of the notice and state that the owner may enter into a real property tax payment plan pursuant to ยง 47-811.05 or pay the amount due, together with any additional interest and penalties, which may be owed prior to the filing date to halt the filing of a complaint pursuant to ยง 47-1392.
The written notice pursuant to paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be sent by first class or certified mail.

At any time after 60 days from the mailing of the notice required by subsection (a) of this section, the Mayor shall cause to be advertised once in not fewer than 2 newspapers of general circulation in the District that are published once every 2 weeks, notice that the listed property will be subject to foreclosure proceedings due to delinquent real property taxes.
A complaint filed to foreclose the right of redemption for a Class 3 or 4 Property based on a real property tax delinquency shall, for each property listed in the complaint, contain:
A description of the real property, by premises address, taxation square, suffix, and lot number, or parcel and lot number;
The names and last known addresses of all interested parties with an interest in the property and, if applicable, a statement that the address of a particular interested party is unknown;
A statement that the real property taxes are delinquent at the time of filing and the amount of taxes owed, including interest and penalties;
The fact that the real property has not been redeemed by an interested party; and
A request that the Court pass a judgment to foreclose the right of redemption of all interested parties with an interest in the real property.

Proof that the property has been registered or designated as vacant or designated as blighted vacant and taxed as Class 3 or Class 4 shall be attached to the complaint and shall be made part of the complaint.
A copy of the notice issued pursuant to ยง 47-1391 shall be attached to the complaint and shall be made part of the complaint.
A complaint filed pursuant to subsection (a) of this section may be amended to include all delinquent taxes on the real property after the commencement of the foreclosure action.
The plaintiff in a complaint filed pursuant to ยง 47-1392 shall be the District.
Each interested party with an interest in the property shall be named as a defendant.
The title of the complaint shall display the last known address of each defendant, as obtained from:
Any record examined as part of the title examination for the property;
The real property records with Office of Tax and Revenue or land records with the Recorder of Deeds; and
Any other likely address that is known to the District.

Other than the methods described in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the District is not required to conduct any further investigations or to search any additional record to ascertain an address for a defendant prior to filing the complaint and undertaking the publication and notice as specified in ยง 47-1394.
Notice to a defendant may be made in any other manner that results in actual notice of the pendency of the action.

If notice is made pursuant to this subsection, the Office of the Attorney General shall file an affidavit with the Court certifying the notice with a description of the method of service used and the time of service.
When the owner of a real property cannot be reasonably ascertained, the unknown owner to the property may be included as a defendant by the following designation:

Unknown owner of [identify the nature of the interest: fee simple, leasehold, or reversionary] interest in the property [give a description of the property in substantially the same form as the description that appears on the pre-complaint notice], the unknown owner's heirs, devisees, and personal representatives and their or any of their heirs, devisees, executors, administrators, grantees, assigns, or successors in right, title, and interest.
Any complaint filed pursuant to ยง 47-1392 against an unknown owner shall attach to it an affidavit by the person making the search stating at a minimum that:
The owner of the real property is unknown; and

A complete search of records for at least 50 years immediately before the filing of the action was performed in accordance with generally accepted standards of title examination of the records of the Recorder of Deeds and the probate decisions of the Superior Court.

At the same time the summons (or initial summons) is issued, the Office of the Attorney General shall obtain an order of publication directed to all defendants, naming them as provided in ยง 47-1393. The order of publication shall:
Describe the real property in the same manner in which it is described in the complaint;
Warn any person that has or claims to have an interest in the property:
To answer the complaint or to redeem the property on or before the date specified in the order of publication; and

That, in the case of failure to appear, answer, or redeem the property, a judgment will be entered to foreclose the right of redemption and order ownership of the real property to be vested in the Mayor.
The date specified in paragraph (2)(A) of this subsection may not be less than 60 days from the issuance of the order of publication.

When the order of publication is issued and published, any person that has any right, title, interest, claim, lien, or equity of redemption in the property is bound by the judgment of the court that may be passed in the case as if the person were personally served with process.
The order of publication shall be in substantially the following form:

para.aftertext: Order of Publication:
The object of this proceeding is to secure the foreclosure of all rights of redemption in and vest title in the Mayor to the following real property:
[Insert description of property in substantially the same form as the description that appears in the complaint.]

The complaint states that the property has been registered or designated as vacant or designated as blighted vacant and taxed as Class 3 or Class 4, taxes are delinquent, and the real property has not been redeemed.

It is thereupon this ... day of...., 20.., by the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, ordered, that notice be given by the insertion of a copy of this order in some newspaper having a general circulation in the District of Columbia, once a week for 3 successive weeks, notifying all persons interested in the real property appear in this Court by the ... day of...., 20.., and redeem the real property by payment of $... or answer the complaint or, thereafter, a final judgment will be entered foreclosing the right of redemption in the real property and vesting in the District a title in fee simple.

para.text: Upon issuance of the order of publication pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, the Office of the Attorney General shall send a copy of the order to each defendant, at the defendant's last known address, by first class or certified mail, postage prepaid.
This subsection only applies to instances when the Office of the Attorney General has ascertained a defendant's last known address.
If a hearing is scheduled, any interested party has the right to be heard and contest the delinquency of the taxes or the adequacy of the proceedings.
The hearing described in paragraph (1) of this subsection shall occur at least 30 days after the filing of the complaint and 60 days from the date of the order of publication.
A guardian ad litem shall be appointed to serve for all interested parties who are or may be minors, or who have been adjudicated incompetent at the date of filing such a list.

In the event that no interested party provides an answer or, if after a hearing on the pleadings and affidavits, the Court finds that the Office of the Attorney General sent notice and a copy of the complaint to each interested party, service of process and other notice requirements have been met, and the information set forth in the complaint is accurate, the Court shall enter a judgment finding:
That proper notice has been provided to all interested parties;
The real property has been registered or designated as vacant or designated as blighted vacant and taxed as Class 3 or Class 4; and
The real property was not redeemed by an interested party; and
Order that the ownership of the real property be transferred to the Mayor in fee simple title.

The judgment entered pursuant to subsection (a) of this section shall be final and conclusive on all defendants, their heirs, devisees, and personal representatives and they, or any of their heirs, devisees, executors, administrators, assigns, or successors in right, title, or interest shall be bound by the judgment as if they had been named in the action and personally served with process.
After entry of a judgment pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, the Mayor shall record a judgment transferring title to the Mayor in the land records with the Recorder of Deeds.
After obtaining and recording a judgment pursuant to ยง 47-1396, the Mayor may:
Convey the property to a land bank; or
Sell the real property at a public auction pursuant to subsection (b) of this section.
If the Mayor intends to sell a real property at a public auction, the Mayor shall publicly notice any Class 3 and 4 Properties that will be sold at a public auction as follows:

In not fewer than 2 newspapers of general circulation in the District that are published once every 2 weeks, the Mayor shall publish a public notice stating the listed real property will be sold at public auction and at the place named in the public notice; and
The Mayor shall include the real property in a list of real property published on the Office of Tax and Revenue's website. The listing shall contain the following:
A description of the real property, by premises address, taxation square, suffix, and lot number, or parcel and lot number;
The name of the person who last appears on the Mayor's tax roll as the owner of the real property; and
The minimum bid required to purchase the property.
The Mayor may sell the real property at auction for an amount less than that required from the owner to redeem the real property.
Before any sale at a public auction, the potential purchaser shall demonstrate that:
He or she has the financial resources available to rehabilitate the property;
He or she has experience rehabilitating properties or has a contract or agreement with a person or organization that has experience rehabilitating properties;
He or she does not have any unresolved notices of infractions related to housing code or property maintenance violations in the District, if applicable; and
He or she is current on all taxes and liabilities owed to the District.

Before making any bid, a potential purchaser shall have on deposit 20% of the purchase price. The deposit shall guarantee full and final settlement for the purchase. If the required deposit is not sufficient, the real property shall be immediately re-auctioned.

The person making the highest bid shall pay the full bid amount to the District of Columbia within 5 business days after the last day of the sale. If the payment is not received within 5 days after the last day of the sale, 20% of the deposit of the defaulting purchaser shall be forfeited to the District, and the real property shall be deemed to have been bid off to and purchased by the Mayor in the name of the District.

If the highest bid for a property sold pursuant to this subsection exceeds the amount of taxes due on the real property, the excess must be refunded, following payment of any recorded liens, to the owner of the record of the property. In the event that no claim for the excess is received by the Mayor within 3 years after the date of the sale, the Chief Financial Officer shall deposit the excess in the General Fund of the District of Columbia.

After payment is received, the Mayor shall issue a deed for any property purchased by a bidder at a sale held pursuant to this section. The deed shall be prima facie evidence of a good and perfect title in fee simple to the real property.
Real property conveyed to a Land Bank or sold at a public auction pursuant to this section shall be conveyed or sold:

"As is." There is no guarantee or warranty of any kind, express or implied, relative to: eligibility to build upon or subdivide the property; zoning classification; size; location; fitness for any use or purpose; or any other feature or condition of a foreclosed property sold pursuant to this section; and
To the highest bidder, if the real property is sold at a public auction.

container.heading: VACANT AND BLIGHTED HOME REVITALIZATION TAX CREDIT.

section.text: Chapter 18 of Title 47 of the District of Columbia Official Code is amended as follows:

para.text: The table of contents is amended by adding a new subchapter designation to read as follows:

container.heading: Vacant and Blighted Property Rehabilitation Credit."

para.text: A new subchapter XIX is added to read as follows:

container.heading: Vacant and Blighted Property Rehabilitation Credit.

para.text: For purposes of ยงยง 47-1819.01 through 47-1819.04, the term:

"Area median family income" means the median family income for the Washington Metropolitan Statistical Area as set forth by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, adjusted for household size.
"Class 3 property" shall have the same meaning as set forth in ยง 47-813(c-9)(4)(A).
"Class 4 property" shall have the same meaning as set forth in ยง 47-813(c-9)(5)(A).

"Eligible development costs" means amounts paid or incurred by an eligible taxpayer after December 31, 2026, for the acquisition, construction, substantial rehabilitation, demolition of structures located on, or environmental remediation of an eligible property.
"Eligible property" means a Class 3 or 4 property registered or designated as vacant or designated as blighted vacant that is:
A house comprised of 4 or fewer residential units or a condominium unit; and
Located in a qualifying census tract as determined by the Mayor as of the date of the application pursuant to ยง 47-1819.04.
"Eligible taxpayer" means a taxpayer certified by the Mayor pursuant ยง 47-1819.04(b) as eligible to claim the credit established under this subchapter.
"Qualifying census tract" means a census tract which has:
A median family income which does not exceed 80% of the median family income of the District;
A poverty rate that is not less than 130% of the poverty rate of the District; and
A median value for owner-occupied homes that does not exceed the median value for all owner-occupied homes in the District.
"Substantial rehabilitation" means amounts paid or incurred for rehabilitation of an eligible property if such amounts exceed $150,000.

For tax years beginning after December 31, 2026, there is established a District of Columbia vacant and blighted home revitalization tax credit that may be claimed against taxes imposed under this chapter.
The amount of the credit shall be 50% of the eligible development costs as certified by the Mayor to the Chief Financial Officer pursuant to ยง 47-1819.04(b).

The credit may exceed the tax liability under this chapter, including any minimum tax due under ยงยง 47-1807.02(b) or 47-1808.03(b), for that taxable year and shall be refundable to the eligible taxpayer, including an organization exempt under ยง 47-1802.01(a)(3) from taxation under this chapter.
The credit may only be allowed if it:
Has been approved and certified by the Mayor to the Chief Financial Officer pursuant to ยง 47-1819.04:
Is claimed by an eligible taxpayer in the taxable year in which the substantial rehabilitation of the eligible property is completed; and
Is claimed in the manner and form prescribed by the Chief Financial Officer.

section.heading: Annual cap.
section.text: The Mayor may approve up to $2,000,000 in credits under this subchapter each fiscal year.

para.text: Before a taxpayer may claim a credit pursuant this subchapter, the taxpayer must apply to the Mayor requesting approval.

If a taxpayer's application is approved in accordance with this subchapter, the Mayor shall certify to the Chief Financial Officer the following on before December 1 of the calendar year following the end of the fiscal year in which the credit was approved:
The name and taxpayer identification number of the eligible taxpayer;
The address of the eligible property (including square and lot);
That the eligible taxpayer's application in accordance with this section was approved;
The date the substantial rehabilitation was completed;
That the eligible taxpayer sold the property to a qualifying homeowner;
The total amount of the eligible development costs incurred by the eligible taxpayer;
The total amount of the credit approved for the eligible taxpayer; and
Any other information requested by the Chief Financial Officer.

container.heading: TAX ABATEMENT FOR THE REDEVELOPMENT OF VACANT AND BLIGHTED COMMERCIAL PROPERTIES.

section.text: Subchapter III of Chapter 8 of Title 47 of the District of Columbia Official Code is amended as follows:

para.text: The table of contents is amended by adding new section designations to read as follows:

section.heading: Tax abatements for the redevelopment of vacant and blighted commercial properties โ Definitions.
Tax abatements for the redevelopment of vacant and blighted commercial properties โ Requirements.
Tax abatements for the redevelopment of vacant and blighted vacant commercial properties โ Abatement period, abatement amount, and caps.
Tax abatements for the redevelopment of vacant and blighted commercial properties โ Rules.

para.text: New sections 47-861.01, 47-861.02, 47-861.03, and 47-861.04 are added to read as follows:

section.heading: Tax abatements for the redevelopment of vacant and blighted commercial properties โ Definitions.

para.text: For purposes of ยงยง 47-861.01 through 47-861.04, the term:
"Class 3 property" shall have the same meaning as set forth in ยง 47-813(c-9)(4)(A).
"Class 4 property" shall have the same meaning as set forth in ยง 47-813(c-9)(5)(A).

"Eligible development costs" means amounts paid or incurred for construction, substantial rehabilitation, demolition of structures, or environmental remediation of an eligible property. Eligible development costs shall not include land acquisition costs.
"Eligible property" means a Class 3 or Class 4 property that:
Shall be redeveloped to be used for commercial purposes as defined in paragraph (5) of this section; and
Has been registered or designated as vacant or designated blighted vacant for at least 12 months without any exemptions pursuant to ยง 42-3131.06a.

"Used for commercial purposes" means use of real property primarily for conducting any trade, business, or profession, whether for profit or not, including providing goods or services or operating as a hotel or inn.
"OTR" means the Office of Tax and Revenue.

section.heading: Tax abatements for the redevelopment of vacant and blighted commercial properties โ Requirements.

para.text: Subject to ยง 47-861.03, the Mayor may approve an abatement of the tax otherwise imposed under this chapter, in an amount calculated pursuant to ยง 47-861.03(a), for an eligible property if:
Eligible development costs exceed $1.5 million;

The property owner, or its designee or assignee, demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Mayor that the abatement shall materially assist the redevelopment project and the redevelopment project would not go forward without the abatement;

The property owner, or its designee or assignee, enters into an agreement with the District that requires the owner, or its designee or assignee, to, at a minimum, contract with certified business enterprises for at least 35% of the contract dollar volume of the construction of the project, in accordance with ยง 2-218.46;
The property owner, or its designee or assignee, executes a First Source Agreement for the construction and operation of the project;

The property owner, or its designee or assignee, requests a letter from the Mayor stating that the proposed redevelopment project is eligible for the tax abatement, setting forth the expected amount of the abatement, as determined pursuant to ยง 47-861.03(a), and reserving that amount for the project; and

The Mayor transmits to the owner the eligibility and reservation letter requested under paragraph (5) of this subsection, subject to such conditions as may be imposed by the Mayor and subject to the adjustment of the abatement amount based on the certifications provided for in ยง 47-860.03(a) and the abatement cap set forth in ยง 47-861.03(b).
The Mayor shall, as nearly as practicable, review requests for eligibility and reservation letters in the order in which each completed request is received.
The Mayor shall transmit to the Office of Tax and Revenue ("OTR") a copy of each eligibility and reservation letter transmitted by the Mayor to an owner pursuant to subsection (a)(6) of this section.

An abatement of the tax otherwise imposed under this chapter shall not be provided for a property for which an eligibility and reservation letter was transmitted by the Mayor pursuant to subsection (a)(6) of this section if the project that was the basis upon which the eligibility and reservation letter was issued has not received a certificate of occupancy within 24 months after the date the eligibility and reservation letter was transmitted; provided, that the Mayor may extend the 24-month period for up to 8 months as deemed necessary.

After the completion of a project for which an eligibility and reservation letter was issued, the Mayor shall, if the conditions set forth in this section and the eligibility and reservation letter have been met, and subject to the abatement cap set forth in ยง 47-860.03(b), issue the property owner a certification of tax abatement, subject to such conditions as the Mayor may impose. The Mayor shall provide a copy of the certification letter to OTR. The certification shall identify:
The property to which the certification applies by square and lot, or parcel or reservation number;
The full legal name of the property owner, including taxpayer identification number;
The tax to which the certification applies;
The portion of the property that is eligible;
The commencement date of the abatement; and
Any other information that OTR shall require to administer the abatement.

The Mayor shall notify the property owner and OTR if any property or owner certified under paragraph (1) of this subsection becomes ineligible for the abatement. The notice shall be written and shall identify the ineligible property, the date that the property became ineligible, and any other information required by OTR to terminate the abatement.

section.heading: Tax abatements for the redevelopment of vacant and blighted vacant commercial properties โ Abatement period, abatement amount, and caps.

para.text: For each property for which a certification of abatement was issued under ยง 47-860.02(e), the real property tax imposed on the property under this chapter shall be abated as follows:
Half of the otherwise applicable tax in each of the first 6 tax years following the tax year during which a certification of tax abatement is issued pursuant to ยง 47-860.02(e);
Two-thirds of the applicable tax in each of the 7th and 8th tax years following the tax year during which a certification of tax abatement is issued pursuant to ยง 47-860.02(e); and
Three-quarters of the applicable tax in each of the 9th and 10th tax years following the tax year during which a certification of tax abatement is issued pursuant to ยง 47-860.02(e).

The total amount of tax abatements the Mayor may approve or certify under ยง 47-860.02 in each fiscal year, including amounts certified in prior years, shall be capped at the following amounts, subject to the availability of funding:
For fiscal years 2027, 2028, and 2029, up to $2,500,000; and
For each succeeding fiscal year after Fiscal Year 2029, up to $3 million.

Prior to the preparation by OTR of tax bills for each half-year installment of tax, the Mayor shall certify to OTR, by a date and in a form and medium prescribed by OTR, each property eligible to receive a real property tax abatement pursuant to a certification issued pursuant to ยง 47-860.02(e), and the portion of the tax to be abated under subsection (a) of this section for each such property with respect to such half-year installment bill.

The certification required by paragraph (1) of this subsection shall be accompanied by a statement from the Mayor specifying the total amount of the tax abatement under subsection (b) of this section for the semiannual period of the certification that is available to abate the taxes of the properties identified pursuant to paragraph (1) of this subsection.

If the amount of tax to be abated for any semiannual billing period for all properties certified under subsection (c)(1) of this section exceeds the total dollar amount of tax abatements available as certified under subsection (c)(2) of this section, the available dollar amount shall be allocated pro rata among all properties certified under subsection (c)(1) of this section.

container.heading: APPLICABILITY; FISCAL IMPACT STATEMENT; EFFECTIVE DATE.

para.text: Sections 104, 105, 106, 202(j), 202(p), 301, 302, 303, 304, and 305 of this act shall apply upon the date of inclusion of their fiscal effect in an approved budget and financial plan.

The Chief Financial Officer shall certify the date of the inclusion of the fiscal effect in an approved budget and financial plan and provide notice to the Budget Director of the Council of the certification.
The Budget Director shall cause the notice of the certification to be published in the District of Columbia Register.
The date of publication of the notice of the certification shall not affect the applicability of the provisions identified in subsection (a) of this section.
